An interesting editorial:
 http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/opinion/oped/bal-op.atheism28oct28,0,3699060.story
 
 It's point is to show why atheists are wrong. The argument goes something like this. Atheists say you shouldn't believe in God because there's no evidence. Kant shows that there exists things of which we are incapable of experiencing. Therefore, given that we know that there are things we can't experience, there's no reason to not believe in God.
 
 I'm perfectly happy with Kant's conclusion that there are things we can't experience, that seems quite reasonable. What I can't accept, and perhaps someone could point out something in the editorial that I missed, is the author's jump from there to "so you're justified in believing anything you like". Logically, and I'm sticking to logic here, it seems to me that the only reasonable conclusion that one can make about a realm you can't experience is no conclusion at all. So sure, saying that there absolutely can't be a God is to make an unsupportable statement. But to say that belief in God is "an unreasonable form of blind faith" seems to be perfectly supported by Kant. Did I miss something, or does the article totally fail to refute the idea that belief in God is simple blind faith, with no more justification than belief in anything else you've never experienced?

 There is no coherent philosophy of atheism (though many philosophies might espouse atheism), no canon of dogmatic atheist beliefs, no ritual, no church and very few real communities of atheists with shared values. Atheists range from the extreme right to the extreme left economically, and from extreme liberal to extreme conservative socially. They are as individualistic a set of free thinkers as you can get.
 
 The only thing atheists ARE agreed on is a lack of belief in any theistic deity.  Well, let's not get into semantic fights about precise definitions -- English is just not that precise a language, and there is usually plenty of room for slight difference of opinion on a meaning. Suffice it to say that my understanding of atheist encompasses a range from people who assert a strong, positive belief that a deity does not and cannot exist; through people who simply have no belief in a deity or think the evidence for a deity is so non-existent, and the reasoning so flaccid, there is no point in believing in one; to people who are philosophically agnostic but functionally atheist. A "true" philosophical agnostic is someone who professes a belief that there isn't enough evidence for or against the existence of a deity, so no opinion may be legitimately held either way. To an agnostic, the existence of a deity is not only unknown but possibly unknowable.
 
 In practice, I find most people who insist on being regarded as agnostics are functional atheists in everything else. Maybe it boils down to how strongly people feel about a belief, and so I often find it helpful to talk about strong vs. weak atheists, depending on the dogmatism and certitude with which they assert their beliefs. And of course, if you define non-belief as a belief of sorts, then I suppose everyone would be a believer in something, but that doesn't really help us much in distinguishing between various types of belief, if everything humans think (or don't think) is classified semantically as a belief. 
 
 I tend to regard "belief in" something as a considerably stronger, more positive statement than "non-belief in" something, which is weaker again than "disbelief in" something; and non-belief is also (IMO) a differentiable state from a formal agnostic position asserting lack of evidence but willingness in principle to go either way. (For example, I am a strong disbeliever in Creationism, a mild-mannered agnostic with respect to the real-world, physical implications of quantum theory, and a non-believer in alien visitations to earth -- I value the nuances here.) But maybe that's just me, and it really isn't worth arguing semantics too strenuously, just so long as folk understand where everyone else is coming from.

 If it wasn't a supernatural event then, from your description, I'd say the most likely scenario is that you had a siezure or a really bad dream, violent enough to shake the bed. In your half-asleep state neither you nor your wife could figure out the source of the shaking.

My wife said as she was standing in the doorway looking at the bed that I sat up in the bed,the mattress was still going from side to side and that I spoke to her and asked. Is it a tremor, is anything on the walls shaking?? I plainly recall saying that..
 
 She said that my body was not shaking, my hands were crossed in my lap not moving, only the mattress was going from side to side. I got out of the bed the second it stopped its sideways movement and she clearly recalls that, as I just asked her to tell me what she recalled seeing back then ...
 
 My wife worked in a hospital for 25 years and said that a person that has just had a violent seizure would surely not be able to stand up, talk as I did coherently with instant alertness, and go get a glass of water without her noticing something wrong with me. ...
 
 Most seizure victims are at the least "disoriented" for the first five minutes after coming out of it. That, and I have never had a seizure that I know of, or my doctor/family knows of. thanks for the reply Kronus.

Most seizure victims are at the least "disoriented" for the first five minutes after coming out of it. That, and I have never had a seizure that I know of, or my doctor/family knows of. thanks for the reply Kronus.

 
 In that case I'll go with bad nightmare and "just woken up" confusion, if we're sticking with mundane explanations. If you were shaking the bed with your hips, and they were under the covers, the source of the shaking might not have been noticed.
 
 If you can recall, how long was your wife awake before you woke up, and how was the room lit, if at all?

I was awakened by the side to side motion of the mattress and sat upright to see my wife in the doorway. That is when I asked her, "Was it a tremor or was anything on the walls moving" ? (we had a tremor in 1990 if I recall correctly) . My wife quickly replied, "No", nothing else is moving ". At that very moment the mattress stopped. ..
 
 She just now told me that she had been in the doorway just a few seconds before I sat up and spoke to her. She is a light sleeper and awoke from the shaking mattress first. She said she turned the overhead light on and saw the mattress going side to side violently, as if something was pushing against it, which was exactly what I was feeling. If I had had a seizure or bad dream and was flailing about, I would have hit my wife during the fiasco. She said she was not touched by me. I did not feel as if my body was moving the mattress, the mattress was moving me. ..
 
 We are both good citizens and hard working honest people with good families and no mental issues. We do not drink (a beer with a pizza once every two months maybe) or do drugs,my wife does smoke cigarettes. We lived in this home alone with two cats and a chow dog. There were other " happenings" in that home that I will not go in to for now. We moved out not long after that incident. thanks Kronus,

 Once, I awoke to the sound of my wife screaming. I ran to the bathroom, the source of the sound, and saw her sitting in the tub with her hair dyed purple. A moment's deep breath and I realized her hair was not purple. She had slipped and fallen into the tub and cut her forehead. I saw the blood and my brain somehow parsed this as dye, and filled in the color on her hair.
 ( The injury wasn't serious, by the way)
 
 My point? Brains don't work well when we've just woken up. They often make erronious connections, make leaps that don't really follow, or miss the obvious. If you want a mundane explanation, that's it. You woke up from a dream bad enough that you shook the bed, and it being 2 in the morning both you and your wife weren't parsing things well. The shaking of the bed freaked you both out enough, and you were both groggy enough, that you didn't quite catch on that you were causing it. If you're looking for a mundane explanation, that seems the most plausible to me. If you want something beyond the mundane, that you already have. But simply put, I wouldn't trust my recollection of something weird that woke me up at 2 in the morning; anything that didn't make sense I would chalk up to my brain not being up to speed yet. But that's just me, without sitting down with you and talking this over with you in depth I don't think I could come up with anything else.
